reason:
P*_lambda(x;q=1,t) > 0 NOT ESTABLISHED: The node defines pi(mu) = F*_mu / P*_lambda, which requires P*_lambda != 0 (and in fact P*_lambda > 0 for the ratio to be a probability). The node never establishes that P*_lambda(x;q=1,t) > 0 for t in (0,1) and x_i > 0.

By Proposition 2.15 of BDW25, P*_lambda = sum_{mu} f*_mu. If some f*_mu could be negative (which is exactly the open question -- see the positivity challenge), then P*_lambda could in principle be zero or negative. Even if all f*_mu >= 0, one needs at least one f*_mu > 0 to ensure P*_lambda > 0.

For the HOMOGENEOUS case: P_lambda = sum f_mu > 0 follows from the probabilistic interpretation (it is the partition function of a well-defined Markov chain, hence positive). But for the INTERPOLATION case P*_lambda, this argument does not directly apply.

If one could establish the ratio identity (Node 1.6), then P*_lambda = P_lambda * (P*_lambda/P_lambda), and positivity of P*_lambda would follow if the ratio P*_lambda/P_lambda > 0. But this requires additional work not present in the node.

The division by P*_lambda is undefined or meaningless unless P*_lambda > 0 is proven.
